page.title: 13BASILDON NE: ST. PETER'S
page.content: {St. Peter's Church}at Nevendon is one of the oldest churches in Basildon. It was built as a chapel for the Lord of the Manor in the 13th. century. Additions were made in 1322. Wood was used extensively in the construction of the church although the panelling inside and the altar dates from l928. Carvings were by local craftsmen, one from Pitsea who was a violin maker. The wooden{coat of arms}dates back to 1780 and is the only one in Essex that has the lion over the crown. A tunnel underground leads from the church to nearby Nevendon Hall and this was used as an escape route for smugglers. Near the church is the Rectory which is about 200 years old. In the grounds is a{tithe barn}which is mentioned in the Domesday Book.
